thread.title: Veteran Plumlee brings personality, leadership to Duke squad
thread.title_full: Veteran Plumlee brings personality, leadership to Duke squad

title: Veteran Plumlee brings personality, leadership to Duke squad
text:
35 Images 
Veteran Plumlee brings personality, leadership to Duke squad 
At seven feet tall and now weighing in heavier than 250 pounds, the pro-wrestling hand gesture that Marshall Plumlee did in his introduction at Countdown to Craziness is about the only way you can't see him clearly. 
"I was hoping people would get the John Cena homage," Plumlee said. "(I'm a) big fan of John Cena." 
The imitation is just one example of how the future US Army officer isn't all drill sergeant, when it comes to comic relief. 
"You would think he's always serious but he's not," Amile Jefferson said. "Marshall has one of the greatest senses of humor of anybody I know. He's witty, he's quick, so the jokes are like, 'Bang-bang.'" 
Plumlee's progression as a player though is no laughing matter. 
"Marshall's a beast," Jefferson said. "And he's finally going to get to show that." 
The youngest of Duke's decorated Plumlee brothers is finally starting to come into his own. 
A breakout performance in the ACC Tournament caught plenty of eyes, but it's the big man's mouth -- his vocal leadership -- that has Mike Krzyzewski's attention. 
"They trust that voice," Krzyzewski said. "Whenever we've had teams that have had good, vocal big men on the defensive end, we've usually been a much better defensive team." 
"Whatever the team needs," Plumlee said, of what role he'll play serve this season. "If we buy into that, we'll be able to do some great things." 
The big man's hustle and loyalty has earned his team's respect...but biceps? He submits that battle to his W-W-E Idol. 
"I don't know if I got the guns like he does," Plumlee said. "But, that was fun for me" Credits
